Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Enforcing the Law in an Authoritarian State: Property Rights Reform in China

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rule of law and secure property rights are thought to be essential ingredients for economic growth and prosperity. But how does the rule of law emerge? Why do some governments enforce laws while others ignore them? This project investigates the origins of the strong legal institutions through a study of property rights in China. Over the past decade, local governments in China have illegally seized land from hundreds of thousands of farmers. Yet in some areas of the country, farmers evidently enjoy stronger protection of their legal rights than in others. According to official statistics, in some provinces less than 1 percent of land seizures are illegal while in others the figure is as high as 24 percent. What explains the relative strength and weakness of property institutions in different areas of China?

To address this question, this project uses multiple methods. A new geospatial dataset of close to a million property seizures will provide a broad picture of what economic and political conditions are associated with increased rule of law. This project includes a comparative analysis of cities in four Chinese provinces. These case studies will provide a more detailed understanding of the processes that allow individuals to act to protect their legal rights and strengthen institutions.

The origins of strong laws and secure property rights are of interest to policymakers as well as scholars. Development agencies often work to build stable institutional foundations that can lead to long-term growth without long-term aid commitments. The issue is also relevant to policymakers who want to build the rule of law in unstable countries that pose potential security threats. The project generates theory and data for these efforts to move from well-designed laws to well-enforced ones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a project that investigated the origins of the rule of law -- focusing on the weakness of ownership rights over property in rural China. Funding under the Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant program allowed the co-PI to travel to China to conduct ten months of fieldwork. This fieldwork included interviews with farmers, government officials, businesspeople, and civil society leaders. The co-PI conducted over 100 in-depth interviews during the grant period. These interviews were complemented by the collection of quantitative data including an original survey and a new nationally-representative dataset of property expropriations

Broader impacts: Protests over government seizures of property are a major source of political instability in China. Close to 100 million farmers have had their land taken by the government. Understanding the root causes of these protests will help policy makers in the United States understand and predict political instability in China and other non-democratic countries. It also is relevant to agencies that want to understand how to bolster the rule of law in countries with weak political order.

Intellectual merit: These questions about the origins of political order and strong property rights are central questions in the social science literature. Both the interview and quantitative data is still being analyzed. The preliminary evidence suggests that increased political inclusion of social elites in village governments frequently backfires for the groups they represent. Although power sharing between political and social elites improves everyday government services, this kind of consolidated power allows local officials to confiscate property.

The findings from this project will be disseminated several ways. The findings will be presented at scholarly conferences over the coming year. The dissertation project will also lead to journal articles and a book.
